title: Psychedelic therapy advocates fear high fees will curb Colorado industry before it starts
description: When psychedelic-assisted therapy becomes available in Colorado next year, the state will be just the second in the U.S. to ...
article_content:
When psychedelic-assisted therapy becomes available in Colorado next year, the state will be just the second in the U.S. to regulate the production and use of psilocybin mushrooms.

Oregon was the first state to legalize psilocybin therapy in 2020 and mental health-focused businesses there began offering it in 2023. Unsurprisingly, local regulators have looked to Oregon for guidance as they develop their own rules and regulations.

There are already lessons to be learned. A year and a half after the nascent industry got off the ground, some of Oregon’s psilocybin service centers are struggling to stay open. One in Portland closed earlier this year after operating for just six months.

Oregon’s service centers are where people go to have a therapeutic psilocybin experience or a guided trip, if you will. (In Colorado, these facilities are called “healing centers.”) But in Oregon, owners say the cost of doing business is so expensive that it threatens the model altogether.

Last June, Dee Lafferty opened Inner Guidance Services in Albany, Ore., which served about 165 clients in its first year. But when the time came to renew her center’s license, which costs $10,000 annually, Lafferty launched a crowdfunding campaign to cover the expense.

“Unfortunately the program in Oregon is not set up in a way to where it is profitable. So we do not have the $10,000,” Lafferty said in a Facebook video promoting her campaign.

But the community stepped up, and within two days, eight people had donated enough money to help Inner Guidance Services reach its goal. While that provided a stopgap, Lafferty doesn’t know how she’ll cover next year’s fee.

“When you look at what you have to pay for the facilitators, for the space, rent, electricity — all of the things that you have to have — what have you to pay sums up to more than what you make reasonably,” she said.

Licensing fees are a hot topic in Colorado, as regulators barrel toward finalizing what it will cost for entrepreneurs to participate in this new industry. It’s one of the last pieces to get settled after they spent a year-plus determining occupational requirements for facilitators and rules governing the business ecosystem surrounding psychedelic therapy.

Challenges like the ones Lafferty described were common in the early days of marijuana legalization, said Rachel Gillette, a Denver-based attorney and head of the cannabis and psychedelics group at the Holland & Hart law firm. Even today, banks, landlords and insurance companies often upcharge businesses that work with federally controlled substances because they’re considered more risky, she said.

Additionally, these businesses are subject to a federal tax code that prohibits them from deducting operating expenses from taxable income, driving up costs.

“Everything seems to come with a little bit of premium on it because it’s something that’s federally illegal,” Gillette said. “Until (psilocybin) loses its stigma, until it’s federally legal in some respect, I think that continues, unfortunately.”

Compliance costs don’t stop with initial licensure, she added. These young industries continually evolve and businesses need to adapt to new regulations. Gillette expects there will be a smaller customer base for psychedelic-assisted therapy because it’s so new and because, unlike cannabis, Colorado won’t permit retail mushroom dispensaries.

“It’s going to take time to build the business so that people understand what it is,” she said. “I don’t see somebody opening their doors for a natural medicine center and having lines out the door like they did on the first day of recreational cannabis. It’s not going to happen.”

Pricy for patients

The solution to sustainability is not as simple as passing costs onto the customer, Lafferty said. Psilocybin services are already notoriously pricy in Oregon, where a single guided trip can cost thousands of dollars for the drugs and for a facilitator who supervises each client while they’re under the influence for several hours. Although psychedelic-assisted therapy is considered a mental health treatment by those in the industry, it’s not yet covered by insurance.

“The biggest thing we learned is that the way the Oregon model is set up, it’s a little bit over the price range for our target market, which we knew, but it’s been confirmed,” Lafferty said.

In its first year, Inner Guidance Services provided the equivalent of $33,000 in free services to individuals who could not afford to pay, Lafferty said. Since opening, she expanded the center’s offerings to include microdosing counseling and introductory low doses for people who are new to psilocybin or hesitant to commit to a large dose. People can also register for group sessions, which are cheaper because the cost is split among several participants.

“We are trying to not close, so we are trying a little bit of everything,” Lafferty said.

Jenna Kluwe, co-owner of the now-shuttered The Journey Service Center in Portland, said the public needs more education so they can see the value of their investment not just for the trip, but also the sessions before and after. Those sessions, called preparation and integration, are integral to long-lasting change, she said. Kluwe’s clients have described a guided psilocybin trip as several years of talk therapy — and therapy on its own isn’t always cheap.

“The value of this needs to be emphasized more and more for folks. Not just the sticker shock, but the value,” said Kluwe.

The Journey Service Center closed in March after its investor halted funding, she said. Kluwe now works at another center called Fractal Soul running its equity program.

Lowering barriers to entry

One difference between the programs in Colorado and Oregon is that the laws here allow healthcare providers to integrate psilocybin therapy into their existing practices. (In Oregon, the businesses, facilities and staff must be separate duplicating costs for current healthcare professionals like Lafferty, a social worker with a private practice.)

Regulators created a micro-healing center license for those places that intend to host just a couple of psilocybin sessions per month versus specializing in that type of treatment. Advocates are adamant the micro-healing center license will lower the barriers to entry in Colorado and streamline access for individuals who already have a therapist or psychiatrist. During a rulemaking hearing on Sept. 16, however, they shared concerns that the currently proposed fees are too high.

In its draft rules, the Department of Revenue proposed micro-healing centers pay $3,000 for application and compliance fees in 2025, before ramping up to a cumulative $5,000 in 2026 and $12,000 by 2027. The phased increase in fees is intended to both incentivize early participation and eventually fund the agency’s administrative work overseeing the industry, regulators said.

Shannon Hughes is a social worker who currently offers ketamine-assisted therapy at her practice, An Enduring Love, in Fort Collins. She sees psilocybin as another tool in the behavioral health toolkit and hopes to integrate it once it’s legal. An Enduring Love gets calls weekly from people interested in trying it.

The most logical way to offer that option would be to obtain a micro-healing center license, Hughes said. But if she had to pay $12,000 per year to do so, “it would not fiscally make sense for our small practice.”

“I really don’t know anybody in the mental health community who that would be viable for,” Hughes said. “So I was disappointed and discouraged because you have to be a large operation to afford $12,000-plus in fees.”

It’s worth noting that all license types, including those for cultivation and manufacturing, will be subject to increased fees by 2027. For example, the latest draft rules dictate a standard healing center – meaning one that intends to specialize in psychedelic-assisted therapy – would be required to pay $6,000 in application and compliance fees in 2025, $8,000 in 2026, and $16,000 by 2027.

“There’s a concern that this current structure and approach will be an inoperable program,” Tasia Poinsatte, director of the Healing Advocacy Fund, said during the recent rulemaking hearing, citing challenges in Oregon. “If we set fees that high and discourage participation today, it’s going to make it that much harder to get this off the ground in the first place.”

Regulators plan to discuss licensing fees again at a meeting on Oct. 21.

title: Gartner Digital Markets hosts the Insights Summit, unveiling 2025’s Software Buying Trends
description: Gartner Digital Markets–the world’s largest platform for finding software and services, including Capterra, GetApp, Software ...
article_content:
Bengaluru (Karnataka) [India], October 1: Gartner Digital Markets– the world’s largest platform for finding software and services, including Capterra, GetApp, Software Advice, and UpCity–recently convened the Insights Summit in India’s Silicon Valley, Bengaluru, Karnataka, to address the SaaS industry’s pressing challenges. After a year of economic uncertainty, SaaS leaders seek innovative strategies to find efficient growth and secure their place on software buyer shortlists.

The Insights Summit featured a distinguished panel of speakers from Gartner Digital Markets, including Narayan Adeeb, VP of India Operations; Pit Rissiek, VP of Sales APAC and EMEA; and Saby Khanduja, Senior Sales Manager. Joining them on stage were SaaS leaders Dhivya Venkatesan, Head of Marketing at Sign easy, and Abhigna Kashyap, Senior Director and Global Head of Brand Content, and Social Media at LTI Mindtree.

The conference theme was “Securing Your Spot on Buyer Shortlists.” The Insights Summit brought together 68 industry experts and thought leaders to provide actionable insights and best practices for SaaS businesses. Participants learned about the latest software buyer trends, emerging technologies, and effective marketing strategies to drive growth.

The event featured exclusive research that surveyed 3,500 software buyers and company decision-makers. The study focused on the challenges of software selection, the latest AI trends and buyer preferences, and strategies for software providers to optimise their performance on the Gartner Digital Markets platform. Additionally, participants had the opportunity to network with other India-based SaaS leaders seeking to accelerate their growth.

Gartner Digital Markets offers objective research and verified reviews to B2B companies searching for software in India through its Capterra India website. As a comprehensive resource, Capterra India is the country’s go-to destination for software search. Software companies use the Gartner Digital Markets platform to reach active buyers and capture demand in India and worldwide.

Key insights discussed in the Insights Summit included:

* Optimistic SaaS spending is forecasted for 2025: 82% of companies surveyed plan to increase their software spending in 2025. India is the most confident of the countries surveyed, planning to increase its spending by 89%. Top priorities for software purchase are Cybersecurity (37%), IT management (31%), and AI (31%).

* Customer reviews: Customer reviews are buyers’ most influential information source for narrowing their initial purchase options and creating a shortlist of products (41%). Final purchase decisions are made predominantly after product trials (62%) and impressions made by the vendor’s customer support (57%).

* Buyer regret: Over half of companies have experienced regret over a technology purchase in the last year. The more a buyer relies solely on information from a vendor to buy software, the more often they experience regret. This makes it more necessary for vendors to boost their credibility through third parties.

* AI adoption: More than a third of decision-makers plan to assess the value and risk of generative AI. From 2024 to 2025, there has been a 70% increase in organisations anticipating challenges evaluating the value and risk of generative AI.

Pit outlined Gartner Digital Markets’ mission to assist software companies in building effective brands through profiles, reviews, and badges. He emphasised capturing in-market demand and gaining insights into market and product sentiment by analysing reviews of your product and competitors. Pit highlighted that building a compelling profile is crucial for brand positioning and noted that cost and pricing are the primary factors buyers consider when searching for software. He emphasised that reviews are pivotal in bringing credibility to your Gartner Digital Markets platform profile.

The event included a panel discussion headed by Saby Khanduja, during which marketing leaders Dhivya Venkatesan and Abhigna Kashyap discussed strategies for making their companies stand out to potential buyers. Topics covered included resource allocation, channel effectiveness, and reputation-building. The discussion was highly interactive, with participants engaging in lively Q&A sessions with the audience and sharing their experiences.

Reflecting on the Insights Summit’s significance, Narayan Adeeb, VP of India Operations of Gartner Digital Markets, says, “The success of the Summit lies in the ambition that the software leaders brought with them along with their trust in us to help them build their brand and capture demand. We were pleased to share our latest research and insights, which expectedly led to some powerful conversations. Most importantly, each interaction with those leading the charge in the industry revitalised our mission to empower organisations towards success with the right technology choices while being impact partners to software providers that would help propel them to new heights.”

About Gartner Digital Markets

Gartner Digital Markets is the world’s largest platform for finding software and services. More than 100 million people visit Capterra, GetApp, Software Advice, and UpCity across over 70 localised sites yearly to read objective research and verified customer reviews that help them confidently choose the right software and services. Thousands of B2B companies work with Gartner Digital Markets to build their brand, capture buyer demand, and grow their business.

Media Contact

Palash Bhattacharjee palash.bhattacharjee@gartner.com

title: 8 project management trends for SMBs in 2024
description: Explore the top project management trends for small businesses. Learn how AI, resource management, and cybersecurity can ...
article_content:
Explore the top project management trends for small businesses. Learn how AI, resource management, and cybersecurity can improve project outcomes. Maskot/Getty Images

Whether it's a new dance on TikTok or a technological breakthrough, trends are a core part of daily life, and the project management landscape is no different. Understanding current trends in project management can influence goals and inspire action — which could lead to bigger and better outcomes for your business.

Knowing the latest project management trends can help you plan better, stay ahead of the competition, overcome common project management challenges, and develop your team efficiently. To that end, we've gathered eight project management trends for 2024 specifically tailored for small businesses.

1. Leveraging artificial intelligence (AI)

Artificial intelligence is the single most significant current trend in project management.

“AI can suggest how to break down tasks into more manageable chunks, and those results can be discussed with the project team,” says Craig Guarraci, founder of Tech PM Career Path, LLC, a career coaching company. He adds that “AI can be used to take meeting notes, determine action items, and to send the notes to attendees, thus freeing up the project manager's time.”

From using generative AI to speed up project planning to leveraging AI's automation capabilities to handle repetitive or menial tasks, businesses are relying more and more on the power of large language models (LLMs) and machine learning to improve project outcomes and reach broader business goals.

Through AI, businesses can also determine what projects they should undertake and learn what other organizations are doing to stay ahead.

“AI could be used by a project manager to brainstorm nearly anything about the project and learn about similar projects,” says Guarraci

2. Putting outcomes over inputs

Especially with growth projects, project managers and businesses are placing a stronger emphasis on the tangible outcomes of projects than the amount of work that goes in. By focusing on outcomes, projects align more with business goals, and project managers can more easily define success.

A key way to focus on project outcomes is through change management — both handling changes throughout a project carefully and efficiently and being mindful of organizational changes a project can cause.

“It's great to complete a project on time, on budget, and within scope, but it's even greater to address change throughout the project lifecycle to ensure [the] realization of benefits,” says Nicole Pietrangelo, project management consultant. “After all, that's the real reason why we're doing projects.”

Project managers and business owners can also pivot toward putting outcomes over inputs by:

Shifting success metrics to highlight deliverables instead of the time spent on a task or the number of tasks completed

Using agile methodologies to keep projects transparent and focused on goals

Working backward from desired long-term goals when planning projects rather than starting from short-term needs or capabilities

3. Hybrid and remote workspaces

Remote and hybrid work arrangements are a major trend in project management and employment, partially due to changes made during the global COVID-19 pandemic.

Many employees and employers have found ways to make remote or hybrid work a cost-saving benefit that also improves some workers' work-life balance and overall happiness. Additionally, Upwork's Future of Remote Work study found that one-third of hiring managers say productivity has increased with remote working.

However, hybrid and remote workspaces create a specific challenge for project management: it’s difficult to communicate and collaborate with your team when they’re spread across the globe.

“Something to be aware of, especially in remote work, is the importance and impact of emotional intelligence and understanding that different people communicate differently,” says Bill Morris IV, Director of Project Management at Morris, a custom thermal solutions company. “As an example, this may mean picking up the phone and calling someone instead of sending a quick email, even if the latter may seem quicker and easier.”

Project management programs and software have responded to this challenge by making communication and collaboration within the program more efficient. Other tools and cloud-based project management software, such as Microsoft Teams, Google Drive, Dropbox, Asana, Monday, and Slack, make asynchronous work more attainable and seamless.

4. Bigger reliance on data

Businesses are turning towards data to drive decision-making at all levels to achieve bigger goals. By using data, outcomes can be better predicted, anomalies can be defined, and failures can be used as tools to achieve greater success in the future.

A key trend in project management is making data-driven decisions from the beginning stages of project planning.

“Data-driven decision-making is very important,” says Joe Bowab, CEO and founder of Lobster Anywhere. “It can help improve efficiency and can help make vital decisions regarding the progress of the project.”

Some of the ways project managers can utilize data more effectively in their projects include:

Basing project success on data-driven metrics

Monitoring data points throughout a project to ensure things are on track

Using historical data to inform decisions

5. Increased focus on cybersecurity

Increasing cybersecurity measures may seem like just an IT project management trend, but cybersecurity attacks can affect every area of a business. Striking a balance between safety and efficiency is a challenging line to toe, but it’s vital for companies to keep their employees and data safe from cyberattacks.

Some ways businesses are improving their cybersecurity in project management include:

Establishing role-based permissions to data and programs

Holding periodic cybersecurity training sessions

Having dedicated cybersecurity experts on staff to review projects and ensure there aren’t any holes

6. Prioritizing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices

Businesses are becoming ever more mindful of ways to minimize their impact on the environment and local communities. As businesses shift toward more sustainable practices, project managers must prioritize ESG practices throughout the project life cycle.

Additionally, business leaders may be relying on project managers to see through environmentally conscious initiatives, especially in areas like infrastructure and energy.

Some ways to keep ESG at the heart of project management are:

Analyzing the environmental impact of project practices and sourcing greener options when possible

Finding ways to make projects benefit local communities and society as a whole in addition to meeting strategic business goals

Crafting ethical standards for projects and meeting local, state, and federal regulatory requirements

7. Being mindful of resource scarcity

With the ever-changing and uncertain economic environment, it’s imperative for companies of all sizes, especially small businesses, to look for ways to stay competitive while staying mindful of their resources. Project managers have to find ways to do more with less, which requires getting creative with project planning and resourcing.

Some ways for businesses to hop on the trend of being mindful of resources include:

Adopting agile methodologies to keep projects efficient

Leveraging technology, like software and AI, to streamline tasks and automate some project aspects

Utilize free project management software and freelance work to minimize project expenses (Try Monday, HubSpot, or ClickUp for free.)

Get stakeholders involved to capitalize on their knowledge and outside perspective

8. Increasing communication and transparency

Project managers have always walked a tight line between transparency and security. On the one hand, keeping a project under tight wraps can prevent information leaks, and having strict silos may allow employees to focus better on their tasks.

However, building a more transparent project environment where communication is encouraged can help introduce new ideas, build a stronger sense of connection to work for team members, and mitigate confusion, especially in large-scale projects. As many teams shift toward agile methodologies, communication is key.

Beyond the rapid technological advancements in project management, managers also must “become expert problem-solvers, critical thinkers, communicators, and leaders,” says Pietrangelo. “While technological advancements lead to new processes and ways of working, project managers need to understand how to guide their teams through change and establish trust during uncertain times.”

Some ways to consider improving your project team’s communication and transparency include:

Utilizing asynchronous communication methods, like Slack or Microsoft Teams

Giving frequent updates on project progress

Promoting cross-team collaboration on projects

Bottom line: Understanding trends in project management

In 2024, staying ahead of the curve means embracing project management trends like leveraging AI, making data-driven decisions, and prioritizing ESG practices. Ensuring your business is flexible and adaptable to the ebbs and flows of the project management landscape is crucial for ensuring your projects meet business goals and deliver meaningful results.

Frequently asked questions

What are the latest trends in project management?

Some of the latest trends in project management include integrating artificial intelligence (AI) into project processes and relying on data to drive decisions. Other trends, like doing more with fewer resources and staying mindful of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices, are crucial for many project management teams.

What are the future trends in project management?

Future trends in project management will rely heavily on technological advances. As AI becomes more broadly integrated, new ways to leverage it for project management are inevitable. Additionally, the environmental impact of projects will continue to be a priority for many businesses, and brainstorming project ideas that can improve how businesses impact and interact with the environment will only become more necessary as climate change evolves.

What are some types of project management?
